snippet: Demonstrators remained defiant Tuesday, pouring into the streets by the thousands and venting their anger over political corruption, the high cost of living and huge public spending for the World Cup and the Olympics.
abstract: Brazil's leaders make conciliatory gestures to try to defuse protests engulfing nation's cities, but demonstrators remain defiant, pouring into the streets by the thousands and venting their anger over political corruption, the high cost of living and huge public spending for the World Cup and the Olympics; protests rank among the largest outpourings of dissent since the nation's military dictatorship ended in 1985.

byline.contributor: Paula Ramon contributed reporting from São Paulo, and Taylor Barnes from Rio de Janeiro.

lead_paragraph: Demonstrators remained defiant Tuesday, pouring into the streets by the thousands and venting their anger over political corruption, the high cost of living and huge public spending for the World Cup and the Olympics.

headline.main: Protests Widen as Brazilians Chide Leaders
headline.print_headline: Protests Grow As Brazilians Blame Leaders
